document_metadata.name: Clearance systems in the brain-implications for Alzheimer disease.

citation.db_name: Clearance systems in the brain-implications for Alzheimer disease.

links.evidence: Emerging evidence suggests that Aβ clearance is impaired in both early-onset and late-onset forms of AD.

citation.db_name: Clearance systems in the brain-implications for Alzheimer disease.

links.evidence: When characterized by autosomal dominant inheritance, EOAD is related to mutations in the presenilin 1 (PSEN1), presenilin 2 (PSEN2) or amyloid precursor protein (APP) genes.

citation.db_name: Clearance systems in the brain-implications for Alzheimer disease.

links.evidence: When characterized by autosomal dominant inheritance, EOAD is related to mutations in the presenilin 1 (PSEN1), presenilin 2 (PSEN2) or amyloid precursor protein (APP) genes.

citation.db_name: Clearance systems in the brain-implications for Alzheimer disease.

links.evidence: When characterized by autosomal dominant inheritance, EOAD is related to mutations in the presenilin 1 (PSEN1), presenilin 2 (PSEN2) or amyloid precursor protein (APP) genes.

citation.db_name: Clearance systems in the brain-implications for Alzheimer disease.

links.evidence: The strongest identified genetic risk factor for LOAD is the apolipoprotein E (APOE) ε4 allele (APOE*ε4),

citation.db_name: Clearance systems in the brain-implications for Alzheimer disease.

links.evidence: although genome-wide association studies have linked LOAD to several other genetic variants, such as TREM2 (triggering receptor expressed on myeloid cells 2), 27 clusterin (CLU),28 and phosphatidylinositol-binding clathrin assembly protein (PICALM).

citation.db_name: Clearance systems in the brain-implications for Alzheimer disease.

links.evidence: although genome-wide association studies have linked LOAD to several other genetic variants, such as TREM2 (triggering receptor expressed on myeloid cells 2), 27 clusterin (CLU),28 and phosphatidylinositol-binding clathrin assembly protein (PICALM).

citation.db_name: Clearance systems in the brain-implications for Alzheimer disease.

links.evidence: although genome-wide association studies have linked LOAD to several other genetic variants, such as TREM2 (triggering receptor expressed on myeloid cells 2), 27 clusterin (CLU),28 and phosphatidylinositol-binding clathrin assembly protein (PICALM).

citation.db_name: Clearance systems in the brain-implications for Alzheimer disease.

links.evidence: The gross pathological changes consist of brain atrophy, particularly in the hippocampal formation, temporal lobes and parietotemporal cortices, accompanied by cortical thinning, enlarged ventricles and white matter abnormalities, as evident on MRI.

citation.db_name: Clearance systems in the brain-implications for Alzheimer disease.

links.evidence: Recent advances now enable several AD-related brain changes to be detected in vivo: 18F-FDG-PET detects decreases in glucose metabolism,45,46 and MRI detects brain atrophy, as well as diffusion and perfu- sion abnormalities, which are most prominent in the vul- nerable hippocampal formation and cortical regions.

citation.db_name: Clearance systems in the brain-implications for Alzheimer disease.

links.evidence: The gross pathological changes consist of brain atrophy, particularly in the hippocampal formation, temporal lobes and parietotemporal cortices, accompanied by cortical thinning, enlarged ventricles and white matter abnormalities, as evident on MRI.

citation.db_name: Clearance systems in the brain-implications for Alzheimer disease.

links.evidence: First, expression of neprilysin is decreased in AD,126 especially in regions with high Aβ loads such as the hippocampus and temporal gyrus.127

citation.db_name: Clearance systems in the brain-implications for Alzheimer disease.

links.evidence: Although overall matrix metallo- proteinase 2 expression is increased in AD, 58 its activity is reduced in astrocytes that surround Aβ plaques.

citation.db_name: Clearance systems in the brain-implications for Alzheimer disease.

links.evidence: In AD, these factors are impaired in a number of ways. First, expression of the blood efflux transporters LRP1 123 and ABCB1 147 is decreased, whereas expression of the blood influx transporter RAGE is upregulated.

citation.db_name: Clearance systems in the brain-implications for Alzheimer disease.

links.evidence: In AD, these factors are impaired in a number of ways. First, expression of the blood efflux transporters LRP1 123 and ABCB1 147 is decreased, whereas expression of the blood influx transporter RAGE is upregulated.

citation.db_name: Clearance systems in the brain-implications for Alzheimer disease.

links.evidence: In AD, these factors are impaired in a number of ways. First, expression of the blood efflux transporters LRP1 123 and ABCB1 147 is decreased, whereas expression of the blood influx transporter RAGE is upregulated.

citation.db_name: Clearance systems in the brain-implications for Alzheimer disease.

links.evidence: First, in ageing, and particularly in AD, CSF production by the choroid plexus is reduced, as shown by decreased water secretion into the ventricles via AQP1 water channels.

citation.db_name: Clearance systems in the brain-implications for Alzheimer disease.

links.evidence: First, in ageing, and particularly in AD, CSF production by the choroid plexus is reduced, as shown by decreased water secretion into the ventricles via AQP1 water channels.

citation.db_name: Clearance systems in the brain-implications for Alzheimer disease.

links.evidence: In AD, the choroid plexus undergoes many structural changes, such as calcification, fibrosis and Aβ deposition, all of which can obstruct CSF production.

citation.db_name: Clearance systems in the brain-implications for Alzheimer disease.

links.evidence: In AD, the choroid plexus undergoes many structural changes, such as calcification, fibrosis and Aβ deposition, all of which can obstruct CSF production.

citation.db_name: Clearance systems in the brain-implications for Alzheimer disease.

citation.db_name: Clearance systems in the brain-implications for Alzheimer disease.

links.evidence: ApoE is a cholesterol transporter that competes with Aβ for efflux by LRP1 from the interstitium into the circula- tion;

citation.db_name: Clearance systems in the brain-implications for Alzheimer disease.

links.evidence: The pres- ence of ApoE4 is associated with reduced perivascular drainage of Aβ,161 which in turn is linked to deposition of immune complexes.

citation.db_name: Clearance systems in the brain-implications for Alzheimer disease.

links.evidence: Soluble Aβ can be removed from the brain by various clearance systems, including enzymatic degradation and cellular uptake, transport across the blood–brain barrier (BBB) and blood–cerebrospinal fluid barrier (BCSFB), interstitial fluid (ISF) bulk flow, and cerebro- spinal fluid (CSF) absorption into the circulatory and lymphatic systems.

citation.db_name: Clearance systems in the brain-implications for Alzheimer disease.

citation.db_name: Clearance systems in the brain-implications for Alzheimer disease.

links.evidence: In the early 2000s, mouse studies demonstrated that the majority (75%) of extracellular Aβ (eAβ) is cleared by the BBB, with only a minority (10%) being cleared by ISF bulk flow.

citation.db_name: Clearance systems in the brain-implications for Alzheimer disease.

links.evidence: Known envi- ronmental risk factors for LOAD include cardiovascular disease, and factors conferring a risk of cardiovascu- lar disease, such as diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Head trauma, physical and mental inactivity, and sleep impairment are additional risk factors for LOAD

citation.db_name: Clearance systems in the brain-implications for Alzheimer disease.

links.evidence: Microscopic changes include accumulation of Aβ into parenchymal senile plaques (also known as neuritic plaques) or in the walls of cerebral capillaries and #arter- ies (known as cerebral amyloid angiopathy, or CAA),as well as aggregation of hyperphosphorylated tau int o intracellular neurofibrillary tangles (NFTs) and neuropil #threads

citation.db_name: Clearance systems in the brain-implications for Alzheimer disease.

links.evidence: Microscopic changes include accumulation of Aβ into parenchymal senile plaques (also known as neuritic plaques) or in the walls of cerebral capillaries and #arter- ies (known as cerebral amyloid angiopathy, or CAA),as well as aggregation of hyperphosphorylated tau int o intracellular neurofibrillary tangles (NFTs) and neuropil #threads

citation.db_name: Clearance systems in the brain-implications for Alzheimer disease.

links.evidence: ecifically, Aβ accumulation into extracellular plaques is marked by decreased CSF levels of Aβ1–42, and tau accumulation into NFTs is marked by increased CSF levels of total tau and hyperphosphory- lated tau.

links.evidence: The most common soluble monomeric isoforms of Aβ are Aβ1-40 (<80%), Aβ1-38 (<20%) and Aβ1-42 (10%).

citation.db_name: Clearance systems in the brain-implications for Alzheimer disease.

links.evidence: Extracellular degradation of ISF proteins mainly consists of degradation by proteases expressed and secreted by cells such as astrocytes

citation.db_name: Clearance systems in the brain-implications for Alzheimer disease.

links.evidence: Specifically, ISF Aβ can be taken up by microglia and astrocytes, whereas perivascular Aβ can be degraded by vascular smooth muscle cells, perivascular macrophages, and astrocytes

citation.db_name: Clearance systems in the brain-implications for Alzheimer disease.

links.evidence: Intracellular Aβ (iAβ) can be degraded by proteasomes via the ubiquitin–proteasome pathway in neurons,116 lyso- somal cathepsin enzymes,117 proteases (such as insulin- degrading enzyme, a thiol metalloendopeptidase that degrades monomeric Aβ) and insulin.

citation.db_name: Clearance systems in the brain-implications for Alzheimer disease.

links.evidence: Intracellular degradation of proteins occurs via the ubiquitin– proteasome pathway, the autophagy–lysosome pathway, and the endosome–lysosome pathway.

citation.db_name: Clearance systems in the brain-implications for Alzheimer disease.

links.evidence: Intracellular Aβ (iAβ) can be degraded by proteasomes via the ubiquitin–proteasome pathway in neurons,116 lyso- somal cathepsin enzymes,117 proteases (such as insulin- degrading enzyme, a thiol metalloendopeptidase that degrades monomeric Aβ) and insulin.

citation.db_name: Clearance systems in the brain-implications for Alzheimer disease.

links.evidence: Tau is mainly cleared through intracellular degrada- tion by lysosomes via the autophagy–lysosome pathway, and by proteasomes via the ubiquitin–proteasome pathway.202

citation.db_name: Clearance systems in the brain-implications for Alzheimer disease.

links.evidence: Intracellular degradation of proteins occurs via the ubiquitin– proteasome pathway, the autophagy–lysosome pathway, and the endosome–lysosome pathway.

citation.db_name: Clearance systems in the brain-implications for Alzheimer disease.

links.evidence: APP is cleaved by α-secretase, which precludes forma- tion of Aβ, and the resulting carboxy-terminal fragment is then cleaved by γ-secretase.103 The resulting products do not aggregate.104

citation.db_name: Clearance systems in the brain-implications for Alzheimer disease.

links.evidence: APP is cleaved by α-secretase, which precludes forma- tion of Aβ, and the resulting carboxy-terminal fragment is then cleaved by γ-secretase.103 The resulting products do not aggregate.104

citation.db_name: Clearance systems in the brain-implications for Alzheimer disease.

links.evidence: If APP is first cleaved by β-secretase 1 (also known as BACE1) instead of α-secretase, the subsequent γ-secretase cleavage will result in soluble monomeric Aβ.

citation.db_name: Clearance systems in the brain-implications for Alzheimer disease.

links.evidence: The most common soluble monomeric isoforms of Aβ are Aβ1-40 (<80%), Aβ1-38 (<20%) and Aβ1-42 (10%).

citation.db_name: Clearance systems in the brain-implications for Alzheimer disease.

links.evidence: Intracellular Aβ (iAβ) can be degraded by proteasomes via the ubiquitin–proteasome pathway in neurons,116 lyso- somal cathepsin enzymes,117 proteases (such as insulin- degrading enzyme, a thiol metalloendopeptidase that degrades monomeric Aβ) and insulin.

citation.db_name: Clearance systems in the brain-implications for Alzheimer disease.

citation.db_name: Clearance systems in the brain-implications for Alzheimer disease.

links.evidence: Extracellular Aβ can also be degraded by proteases, such as neprily- sin (a membrane-anchored zinc metalloendopeptidase that degrades the Aβ monomers Aβ1-40 and Aβ1-42, and Aβ oligomers),119 matrix metalloproteinases 2, 3 and 9,120 glutamate carboxypeptidase II,121 endothelin-converting enzyme,122 tissue plasminogen activator,123 plasmin,120 angiotensin-converting enzyme,120 and insulin-degrading enzyme.

citation.db_name: Clearance systems in the brain-implications for Alzheimer disease.

links.evidence: Second, both Aβ and insulin are ligands that compete for degradation by insulin-degrading enzyme; thus, hyper- insulinaemia can reduce clearance of Aβ, which might partly explain the link between type 2 diabetes mellitus and AD.

citation.db_name: Clearance systems in the brain-implications for Alzheimer disease.

links.evidence: In addition, insulin-degrading enzyme has been proposed to have a role in Aβ clearance through the BBB, which might explain why BBB clearance is sensitive to insulin.144

links.evidence: In AD, these factors are impaired in a number of ways. First, expression of the blood efflux transporters LRP1 123 and ABCB1 147 is decreased, whereas expression of the blood influx transporter RAGE is upregulated.
